Geoengineering technologies aim to modify the Earth's energy balance to counteract climate change, raising environmental and ethical concerns. Proposed technologies vary in characteristics and consequences, classified into solar radiation. Proposed geoengineering technologies are classified into Solar radiation management (SRM) and Carbon dioxide removal (CDR) methods. SRM methods aim to increase Earth's reflectivity, while CDR methods focus on removing CO2 and other GHGs from the atmosphere. SRM methods could have immediate climate impacts, but if they fail, global warming could resume rapidly. Some SRM methods are already being deployed, while CDR methods include afforestation and ocean fertilization.
